question.title: Has anyone developed a method to set the size of the first form in a codename one/javase app being built for Windows Desktop?
question.body:
I have started testing my code on both macOS and Windows Desktops before I build for the iPad. The macOS build opens at almost iPad Mini size and everything in the app is useable. When the build opens on Windows Desktop, the screen is approximately 3.5" x 4" in size. Though I can immediately resize the form when the app opens, the PreferredSize has been stored, and when I get to the form where the user designs exercises and plays, my ScaleImageLabels are two-thirds the size of the macOS build, and the iPad Mini Simulator screen I develop on, which makes the small SILs used in the design hard to drag and drop.

Even thought setPreferredSize for a form is not recommended, I need the form to open at approximately 5" x 7" so the small SILs are draggable. Because of the different resolutions of monitors, I would only set the minimum size of form 1 to make sure the SILs are large enough drag when the user gets to that phase in the app.

I thought of running a method such as:

if (Windows.Desktop) {
    form.setPreferredSize(350, 550);
}

but I cannot find a search statement in Google that leads me to any useable information. I have found the ways to Style the components in the theme, but I have to set an acceptable size for the first form.

Thanks for any ideas.

Edit 1

The TLAssistStub sets the AppWidth at 800, Height at 600, but the app opens at 3 5/8" x 3". Below is the app opening size with the TLAssistStub on Windows 11, Parallels, MovebyDrag.class, showing smaller players and the ball a dot in front of 9, and the same code building macOS Desktop app opening on 16" MacBook Pro, full screen capture, MovebyDrag.class, showing iPad Mini-size players and the ball drawn at a useable size. I will rebuild with FullScreen = true, but I am trying to open the app at 5" x 7" and grow from there.

answers.body: I think you meant to post this as a question and not as a best practice. The best way to do this is probably using a native interface where you can use JavaSE Swing/AWT code to size the JFrame to any size you want. You don't need to manipulate the preferred size of the form for this to work.

I did not realize I was not in the Questions Section. I am building the app so information could be developed on the desktop and emailed to the tablet for use at a game or practice. Codename One will not create a JFrame, so I must have the app identify the desktop build and open the form large enough to not shrink the ScaleImageLabels, unless I am having an issue with the app getting the preferred size of the size-adjusted form created to design the activities before the SILs are initialized. The glass pane and content pane grids are the correct size on the size-adjusted form, but the SILs on the both panes are 66% the size of those on the same screen in the macOS build.

I suggest filing an RFE/issue in the Codename One github project. We can probably implement some kind of strategy that makes sense for you e.g. a flag that would set the window to a given size based on percentage of display size or maybe an API to set window size.

Will do. I sent an email in to Codename One support with 2 more comparison pictures and my hypothesis about the initial size of the Windows JFrame affecting the SpanLabels, layout managers and icons. I asked Lianna to send it to you and Steve. The biggest question for me is why the size of the macOS javase JFrame is of a sufficient size to define a solid foundation for the measurements, and the Windows build JFrame from the same code starts out at 1/3 the size.

I'll have to look at that. I think there's room to add a window API to Codename One that will give you callbacks applicable to desktop applications that you can leverage to custom size everything.

The window sizing code for Mac OS/Windows is effectively identical, but there are platform differences such as base theme, JVM etc. that might impact the result.

For those interested in the details of what I have found, my reports are entered in Github Codename One, assigned issue #4145.

I apologize for not checking here last night before I shut down. In addition to what I reported on Github in my afternoon report:

Since all my buttons are Styled by purpose, I have only found 2 other issues I have not mentioned.

  1. Natural labels (tied to PreferredSize) which I had not Styled displayed at 1mm. Assigning the UIID yesterday to those labels I previously missed corrected this.

  2. 1 container I added a Styled label and Styled button to clipped the top and bottom of the text. The size of the container grew when the JFrame was resized, but the PreferredSize of the area in the container where the text is assigned did not grow. I will work on that container today and report back.

After what I identified yesterday and discussed on Github, I can Style around everything but PreferredSize, and if the Windows (or Desktop) API only allowed me to set the size of the JFrame for the initial form, I could adjust that starting point for PreferredSize and I think everything would fall into a useable place. As I noted in my report from yesterday afternoon, I think a starting size of 1280 x 1080 would work for both platforms.

If you are using Properties and are having display issues in the Windows Desktop build of your app with your use of the auto-generated user interface created in the method below, it could be tied to this issue.

createMagicalContactEditorContainer(Contact c)
Shai, does Maven relay Stub.java in the javase code information to the build engine when we run the build desktop goal? I tried a change, but the change was not recognize.
Stub is regenerated every time. You can't change that. You can however use a native interface on the start method so there's no need to change the stub.

Understood. I will see what I can experiment with while you work through your thoughts on the potential for a defined Desktop API. Thanks for your thoughts and the time you allocate for all the issues you work to improve. I hope my observations posted in the issue notes on Github have added to the thought process.
Please see "How can I use code to set my initial Form size when my app opens?" for my final report and workaround for this issue.

With CodenameOne 7.0.213 that came out this week you can invoke:

CN.setInitialWindowSizeHintPercent(new Dimension(80, 80));

This will set the initial size to 80% of the available screen both for width and height. Make sure to invoke it early enough in the program lifecycle e.g. in the init(Object) method. After that there are some new APIs to get the desktop size and listen to window events.
